<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 390, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 AS Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>

No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 559]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 602]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 729, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 60.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 73, 126, 88]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 101, 688, 530]]<|/det|>
acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00 \times 10^{8} \text{m s}^{- 1}\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60 \times 10^{- 19} \text{C}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1 \text{u} = 1.66 \times 10^{- 27} \text{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67 \times 10^{- 27} \text{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11 \times 10^{- 31} \text{kg}\) Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02 \times 10^{23} \text{mol}^{- 1}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31 \text{J K}^{- 1} \text{mol}^{- 1}\) Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38 \times 10^{- 23} \text{J K}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67 \times 10^{- 11} \text{N m}^{2} \text{kg}^{- 2}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85 \times 10^{- 12} \text{F m}^{- 1}\) \(\left(\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}}\right) = 8.99 \times 10^{9} \text{m F}^{- 1})\) Planck constant \(h = 6.63 \times 10^{- 34} \text{J s}\) Stefan- Boltzmann constant \(\sigma = 5.67 \times 10^{- 8} \text{W m}^{- 2} \text{K}^{- 4}\)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 565, 168, 581]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 809, 89]]<|/det|> The rate of flow \(Q\) of a liquid along a narrow pipe of length \(L\) and radius \(r\) is given by <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[462, 95, 539, 123]]<|/det|> \[Q = \frac{\alpha r^4}{L}\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 304, 151]]<|/det|> where \(\alpha\) is a constant. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 165, 920, 198]]<|/det|> An experiment is carried out to determine the value of \(\alpha\). The data from the experiment are shown in Table 1.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 212, 541, 229]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 242, 841, 344]]<|/det|>
quantityvaluepercentage uncertainty
\(Q\)\(2.72\times 10^{-8}\mathrm {m}^{3}\mathrm {s}^{-1}\)\(\pm 3\%\)
\(r\)\(7.1\times 10^{-5}\mathrm {m}\)\(\pm 2\%\)
\(L\)\(2.5\times 10^{-2}\mathrm {m}\)\(\pm 4\%\)

Give your answer to an appropriate number of significant figures. <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 774, 920, 794]]<|/det|> \[\alpha = \left( \begin{array}{c c c c c c c c c c c c c c c c c c c c c c c c c c c c c c c}{} & {} & {} & {} & {} & {} & {} & {} & {} & {} & {} & {} & {} & {} & {} & {} & {}\\ {} & {} & {} & {} & {} & {} & {} & {} & {} & {} & {} & {} & {} & {} & {} \end{array} \right) \times 10^{7}\mathrm {s}^{-1} \quad [3]\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 806, 920, 823]]<|/det|> [Total: 5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
The engine of a toy rocket pushes gases vertically downwards and this results in the rocket accelerating vertically upwards from the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
The rocket starts to move from rest at time \(t = 0\). The variation with time \(t\) of the vertical velocity \(v\) of the rocket for the first \(0.30 \text{s}\) of the flight is shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[134, 161, 841, 476]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 491, 532, 510]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 522, 752, 541]]<|/det|>
As the rocket moves, the thrust force \(T\) provided by the rocket engine is \(16 \text{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 537, 695, 556]]<|/det|>
Assume that the mass of the rocket is constant for this part of its flight.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 568, 447, 586]]<|/det|>
Assume that air resistance is negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 600, 146, 618]]<|/det|>

For this part of the rocket's flight:

<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 195, 920, 227]]<|/det|>
A hollow plastic sphere is attached at one end of a bar. The sphere is partially submerged in water and the bar is attached to a fixed vertical support by a pivot P, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[166, 242, 803, 530]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 549, 591, 567]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 580, 920, 613]]<|/det|>
The sphere has weight \(0.30 \text{N}\). The distance from P to the centre of gravity of the sphere is \(0.29 \text{m}\). Assume that the weight of the bar is negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 625, 636, 643]]<|/det|>
Calculate the moment of the weight of the sphere about P.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[497, 749, 920, 766]]<|/det|>
<form>moment = .................................................... $N \text{m}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[893, 749, 920, 766]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
The system shown in Fig. 3.1 is part of a mechanism that controls the amount of water in a tank.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 118, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
Water enters the tank and causes the sphere to rise. This results in the bar becoming horizontal. Fig. 3.2 shows the system in its new position.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[175, 163, 803, 344]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 364, 591, 382]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.2</label> <label>(not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 395, 920, 429]]<|/det|>
In this position the rod R exerts a force to compress a horizontal spring that controls the water supply to the tank. R is positioned at a perpendicular distance of \(0.017 \text{m}\) above P.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 444, 920, 477]]<|/det|>
The variation of the force \(F\) applied to the spring with compression \(x\) of the spring is shown in Fig. 3.3.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 490, 779, 875]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 894, 534, 912]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 181, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 685, 90]]<|/det|>
Use Fig. 3.3 to calculate the spring constant \(k\) of the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 241, 922, 260]]<|/det|>
<form>k = ............................................... N m⁻¹ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 273, 181, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 272, 821, 291]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 303, 920, 337]]<|/det|>
The radius of the sphere is \(0.0480 \text{m}\) and \(26.0\%\) of the volume of the sphere is submerged.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 335, 534, 353]]<|/det|>
The density of water is \(1.00 \times 10^{3} \text{kg} \text{m}^{-3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 365, 583, 383]]<|/det|>
Show that the upthrust on the sphere is \(1.18 \text{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 536, 920, 555]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 567, 181, 586]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 566, 883, 586]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[522, 828, 920, 847]]<|/det|>
<form>force = .................................................... N [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 180, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 255, 920, 275]]<|/det|>
<form>E_{\mathrm{p}} = .................................................... J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 319, 510, 337]]<|/det|>
Assume that resistive forces are negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 350, 920, 384]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 454, 920, 472]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 121]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 616, 152]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 395, 89]]<|/det|>

<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 195, 918, 227]]<|/det|>
Three identical cells, each of electromotive force (e.m.f.) 1.5V and internal resistance 590 mΩ, are connected in parallel across a conductor, as shown in Fig. 5.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[344, 237, 650, 555]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 574, 532, 592]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 5.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 621, 675, 638]]<|/det|>
The conductor is composed of two cylindrical sections A and B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 636, 499, 653]]<|/det|>
The total resistance of the circuit is \(2.2 \Omega\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 667, 181, 685]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

The two cylindrical sections A and B of the conductor in Fig. 5.1 are made from the same material and have the same length.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 240, 784, 259]]<|/det|>
The diameter of section A is \(4.3 \text{mm}\) and the diameter of section B is \(7.6 \text{mm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 256, 737, 275]]<|/det|>
The resistance of section A is \(R_{\mathrm{A}}\) and the resistance of section B is \(R_{\mathrm{B}}\).

<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 282, 388, 312]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[537, 447, 920, 485]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{R_{\mathrm{A}}}{R_{\mathrm{B}}} = \mathrm{....................................................} \quad [3]\]

The circuit of Fig. 5.1 is altered by removing one of the cells.

<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
The nuclide \(^{14}_{6}\mathrm{C}\) (carbon-14) is unstable and undergoes \(\beta^{- }\) decay, emitting a high-energy electron and an antineutrino to form a new nuclide X. The equation for this decay is shown.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[319, 121, 680, 155]]<|/det|>
\[{}^{14}_{6}\mathrm{C}\rightarrow \mathrm{......X} + \mathrm{......e}^{-} + \mathrm{}^{0}_{0}\mathrm{V}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 351, 199]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 490, 920, 526]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 536, 875, 555]]<|/det|>
